author: mratsim
content:
Alternatively, something like Curve4Q might be fast for you? 

Go implementation: https://github.com/cloudflare/circl

writeup: https://bifurcation.github.io/fourq/

It's based on 2^127-1 extension field which should be decently fast.


Or alternative 2, use a Curve on an extension like https://github.com/pornin/ecgfp5
which uses Goldilocks (2^64 - 2^32 + 1) base field with extension of degree 5.

author: mratsim
content: bonus: it's cheap to prove in Plonky2 / Goldilocks based proof systems

author: mratsim
content: For what is worth, Ukrainian digital identity is using binary curves: https://github.com/ikripaka/dstu4145-rust/pull/1

author: potuz
content: Thanks yeah alternative 2 will lead to better bandwidth,  do you know how these two curves compare ? (Speed of MSM)

author: mratsim
content: you still use extension fields so you send 5x 64 bits for EcGfp5

author: mratsim
content: basically small base field --> extension fields needed to grow the number of bits

author: mratsim
content: now there might be way to store points in a compressed form but I don't know enough of this curve for it.

author: mratsim
content:
Curve4Q has a 4 dimensional endomorphism, I expect the speedup is similar to BLS G2 with/without endomorphism.

Goldilocks can be implemented without carries on a 64-bit CPU meaning it's extension field benefits maximally from instruction-level parallelism (4 independent additions in 1 CPU cycle on Intel CPUs, 6 on Apple Silicon).

All to say, i have absolutely no idea.
